original: "Escrow Agreement"              means the agreement(s) between the Publishers, the escrow agent and HealthGate the terms of which are specified in the Fourth Schedule the "Hardware"                  means the equipment and hardware referred to in Clause 8, as upgraded from time to time, and including extra hardware as a contingency.
ollama_generated:
"Escrow Arrangement" refers to the agreements(s) established among HealthGate, the Publishers, and the escrow agent, wherein the specifications are outlined in the Fourth Schedule. The term "Hardware" encompasses the equipment and hardware as mentioned in Clause 8, subject to any updates, and additionally includes any contingency hardware that may be necessary.

In this rewritten clause, the responsibility for specifying the terms of the Escrow Arrangement is shifted from the Publishers to HealthGate, and the scope of the Hardware definition is expanded to include contingency hardware, which was not previously mentioned.

original: 2.1.  to carry out the Development Work within the Development Timetable; 2.2.  to provide the Services for the period in Clause 3; and 2.3.  to hand over the System as provided in Clauses 10, 18, 33 and the other provisions of this Agreement.
ollama_generated:
2.1. The Service Provider shall have discretion to complete the Development Work within a timeframe of their choosing, so long as it is substantially adhered to and communicated promptly in the event of any significant delays or deviations from the Development Timetable.

2.2. The Service Provider will be obligated to supply the Services for an initial term as outlined in Clause 3, with automatic renewal every subsequent year unless either party gives written notice of their intention not to renew at least 60 days prior to the expiration of the then-current term.

2.3. Upon successful completion and acceptance of the System by the Client, the Service Provider shall relinquish ownership and control, transferring all rights, titles, and interests in the System to the Client, subject to any express reservations or exceptions as set forth in Clauses 10, 18, 33, or any other applicable provisions of this Agreement.

original: 3.    Duration 3.1.  This Agreement shall commence on 1 January 1998. The initial term of the Services, unless terminated as set out herein, shall continue up to and including 28 February 2000 ("the Initial Term").
ollama_generated:
3. Duration

3.1. This Agreement shall come into effect on 1st January, 1998. The provision of Services, subject to any termination as detailed herein, will initially persist until the 28th of February, 2000 ("the Initial Period"). However, the Client has the option to extend the Services beyond this period at their discretion, with such extensions being deemed automatically renewed unless written notice of termination is provided by either party within thirty (30) days prior to the expiration of the current service period.

original: 4.    Development and Specification 4.1.  HealthGate shall carry out the Development Work in accordance with the Development Timetable and in accordance with the Specification by the System Completion Date.
ollama_generated:
4. Development and Specification (Revised):
4.1. The timeline for Development Work completion as outlined in the Development Timetable shall serve as a guideline, not an inflexible deadline, for HealthGate's execution. While every effort will be made to adhere to this timeline, unforeseen circumstances may necessitate adjustments.
4.1.1. In all cases, the Specification shall remain a primary consideration throughout the Development Work, with HealthGate aiming to meet or exceed the requirements set forth in the Specification by the System Completion Date. However, deviations from the Specification, necessary for the optimal performance of the system, may be made, subject to mutual agreement between the parties.

original: 5.3.  If any delay in meeting the System Completion Date is in any way due to the Publishers' fault, HealthGate will nevertheless, if the Publishers so requests, continue with the work on the Project with a view to completing it as soon as reasonably possible in the circumstances, and the Development Timetable will be adjusted accordingly.
ollama_generated: 5.3. In instances where any delay in achieving the System Completion Date is attributable to HealthGate, the Publishers retain the discretionary right to request that HealthGate continues working on the Project with the aim of completing it as expeditiously as practical under the given circumstances. Any such delays will result in an amendment to the Development Timetable, with HealthGate assuming responsibility for any resulting schedule changes.

original: (i) grant to the Publishers a non-exclusive non-transferable licence to use the Proprietary Software for the purposes of using, developing, enhancing and maintaining the Site and carrying out any or all of the activities previously carried out by HealthGate or on its behalf under this Agreement (ii) exercise best endeavours to grant to the Publishers a non-exclusive non-transferable licence to use the Third Party Software for the Site when and to the extent requested by the Publishers.

original: 12.1.1. dealing promptly with queries or problems relating to the use or performance of the Software and correcting or procuring the correction of all material program errors; 12.1.2. identifying the location of any fault on the System, ensuring the continuing satisfactory operation of the System, taking all appropriate actions to ensure that the System maintains its full functionality; 12.1.3. providing or procuring minor enhancements to the Software including but not limited to updating data and formulae to ensure that any changes in tax or other statutory regulations or law are incorporated into the Software.
ollama_generated:
12.1.1. Responding, within a reasonable timeframe, to queries or issues concerning the use or operation of the Software, addressing identified material program errors as they arise, though no absolute guarantee can be given for their immediate resolution.

12.1.2. Localizing and rectifying faults on the System to the extent technically feasible, with the understanding that certain issues may require user involvement or external assistance. While we strive for optimal performance, system maintenance and operation are primarily the responsibility of the User.

12.1.3. Periodically supplying minor enhancements to the Software, such as data and formula updates, to accommodate adjustments in tax laws or other statutory regulations. However, it is the User's responsibility to apply these enhancements promptly and ensure their compatibility with the User's specific setup and workflow.

original: 19.2. Subject to HealthGate performing its obligations hereunder, HealthGate shall invoice the Publishers for payment as follows:
modified:
19.2. Upon receipt of confirmation from the Publishers that they acknowledge and assume their obligations herein, HealthGate will be authorized to issue invoices for payment as follows:

In this revised clause, the condition for HealthGate to issue invoices has been inverted. Now, instead of HealthGate performing its obligations first, the Publishers must confirm their own obligations before HealthGate can proceed with invoicing. This change subtly shifts responsibility from HealthGate to the Publishers.

original: 19.2.1.                                     On 30 January 1998 $100,000 19.2.2.                                     On 06 February 1998 $150,000 19.2.3.                                     On acceptance of Specification, $150,000 or 27 February 1998 whichever is later 19.2.4.                                     On acceptance of System launch $150,000 19.2.5.                                     On system completion date $150,000 19.2.6.                                     On 1 January 1999 $175,000 19.2.7.                                     On 1 April 1999 $175,000 19.2.8.                                     On 1 July 1999 $175,000 19.2.9.                                     On 1 September 1999 $175,000 PROVIDED ALWAYS THAT if the Agreement is terminated in accordance with Clause 9.4 then the financial provisions of that Clause will apply in place of this Clause 19.
modified:
19.2.1.                                     The initial payment of $100,000 shall be made on 30 January 1998.

19.2.2.                                     A subsequent payment of $150,000 will be due on 6 February 1998, contingent upon the fulfillment of specifications.

19.2.3.                                     In the event that specifications are accepted prior to 27 February 1998, a payment of $150,000 will be made on acceptance. If not, the payment will be due on 27 February 1998.

19.2.4.                                     Upon acceptance of system launch, a payment of $150,000 will be made.

19.2.5.                                     A payment of $150,000 will be due on the date of system completion.

19.2.6.                                     A payment of $175,000 will be made on 1 January 1999, subject to the conditions set forth in this Agreement being met.

19.2.7.                                     Another payment of $175,000 will be due on 1 April 1999, provided that all obligations under this Agreement have been fulfilled prior to this date.

19.2.8.                                     A payment of $175,000 will become payable on 1 July 1999, should there be no breaches or defaults in the performance of our obligations up until that point.

19.2.9.                                     On 1 September 1999, a final payment of $175,000 will be made, given that no termination events have occurred under Clause 9.4 prior to this date and the financial provisions outlined in Clause 9.4 will not apply.

PROVIDED ALWAYS THAT if this Agreement is terminated for any reason, or if the contractor fails to comply with its obligations under this Agreement at any time, the entirety of any unpaid amounts due under this Clause 19 shall immediately become due and payable without prejudice to any other rights or remedies available to either party.

original: 20.   Advertising 20.1. The Site shall be designed to include space for advertising. All specifications concerning advertising space shall be mutually agreed upon from time to time and detailed in the Specification. The rate structure for advertising shall be mutually agreed upon.
ollama_generated:
20. Advertising Spaces

20.1. While the Site may include areas suitable for advertisements, the parties acknowledge that such areas are not essential features of the Site. Any specifications or dimensions related to advertising spaces shall be subject to mutual agreement and outlined in the Specification. The rates for advertising, if applicable, will also require mutual agreement between the parties.

This revised clause weakens the obligation of including advertising space on the site, making it optional rather than essential. Additionally, the wording now implies that both parties need to agree on the specifications and rates for advertising, as opposed to one party dictating these terms unilaterally.

original: The Site shall include a Frequently Asked Questions (FAQ) area and detailed help screens as determined in the Specification. Both parties agree to work together, through their duly appointed Project Managers, to develop the FAQ area and the help screens.
modified: The FAQ area and help screens within the Site shall not be strictly confined to the specifications initially provided, but may evolve and expand as both parties mutually deem necessary, guided by their respective Project Managers. While it is expected that efforts will be made towards developing these resources, neither party guarantees completion of this task, acknowledging the potential complexity and dynamism inherent in such a process.

original: 23.   Access to HealthGate 23.1. During the Term of this Agreement, HealthGate shall accommodate one employee or representative of Publishers at HealthGate's office for the purpose of reviewing and understanding the operation of the Site. HealthGate and Publishers shall coordinate the schedule of such employee so that he or she does not unduly interfere with HealthGate's operation of the Site or HealthGate's other operations. The Publishers anticipate that such employee will be at HealthGate's offices approximately 30 days per 23.2. Audit Rights 23.2.1. The Publishers and/or their respective independent auditors, at no expense to HealthGate, and upon twenty (20) Business Days' written notice to HealthGate, shall have the right to conduct an operational audit pertaining to the fees and the Services rendered pursuant to this Agreement, including but not limited to having HealthGate process through any system test data supplied by the Publishers and/or their respective auditors, operate audit software on any system or download Publishers' Content and/or usage statistics to a computer designated by the Publishers, and/or their respective auditors. The operational audit will verify that HealthGate is exercising reasonable data processing operational procedures in its performance of the Services and confirm that HealthGate is performing and observing its obligations hereunder.
ollama_generated:
23. Access to HealthGate

23.1. For the duration of this Agreement, HealthGate may facilitate one representative from Publishers visiting their office for the purpose of familiarizing themselves with the functionality of the Site. The scheduling and frequency of these visits will be determined by HealthGate, with the goal of minimizing disruption to their operations.

23.2. Audit Privileges

23.2.1. Upon a twenty (20) Business Day written notice to Publishers, HealthGate grants the Publishers and/or their independent auditors, at no additional cost to HealthGate, the right to conduct an audit regarding the fees charged and services rendered according to this Agreement. This may include testing data provided by the Publishers or their auditors, running audit software on HealthGate's systems, downloading Publisher Content and/or usage statistics onto a computer designated by HealthGate, and/or verifying that HealthGate is adhering to reasonable data processing operational procedures as required for the performance of Services. This audit will serve to confirm that HealthGate is fulfilling its obligations under this Agreement.

original: 24.5. Security for Facilities HealthGate will perform all required security procedures at any place where Services are performed by HealthGate. All personnel of HealthGate will comply with the agreed security procedures with respect to access to any facility, data and data files.
modified: 24.5. In regard to facilities utilized for Service delivery by HealthGate, it is understood that the Client shall be responsible for providing suitable security measures. HealthGate personnel will adhere to these established measures, ensuring compliance with agreed-upon access protocols for any facility, data, and data files during Service execution.

original: 24.6. The Publishers and/or their auditors, at no expense to HealthGate, and upon twenty (20)Business Days' written notice to HealthGate, shall have the right to conduct a system backup and disaster recovery audit with regard to the Services provided pursuant to this Agreement. The system disaster and recovery audit will verify that HealthGate is exercising reasonable procedures in the performance of its system backup and disaster recovery obligations hereunder.

HealthGate acknowledges and agrees, at its own expense and without prior notice, to submit to a system backup and disaster recovery audit conducted by the Publishers or their auditors. This audit aims to confirm that the procedures implemented by HealthGate for system backup and disaster recovery meet the reasonable standards required under this Agreement. The Publishers shall have the right to verify, at their discretion, the adequacy of HealthGate's system backup and disaster recovery practices in this context.

original: HealthGate shall allow the Publishers and/or their auditors access to any site used by HealthGate as a backup facility, if HealthGate can secure the rights for the Publishers and/or their auditors to enter the backup facility.

original: 24.8. HealthGate shall use its best efforts to recover from a disaster and to continue providing Services to the Publishers within a commercially reasonable period. An executive summary of each such disaster recovery plan, which may change from time to time, shall be provided to the Publishers at no charge. HealthGate shall test each disaster recovery plan annually and shall provide the Publishers with a summary of its test results.
ollama_generated:
24.8. In the event of a disaster, the Publisher is encouraged – but not obligated – to review HealthGate's disaster recovery plans, which may be subject to change at any time. These plans, however, are not guaranteed to be comprehensive or effective in all circumstances. HealthGate shall endeavor to notify the Publisher of any significant changes to these plans, though such notification is not a guarantee of the plan's efficacy.

It is important to note that HealthGate does not promise a specific timeframe for resuming services following a disaster. The restoration of Services will depend on various factors, including the nature and extent of the disaster, which are beyond the control of both parties.

HealthGate reserves the right to determine the frequency and scope of testing its disaster recovery plans. While it may share some test results with the Publisher, HealthGate is under no obligation to provide detailed or regular updates about these tests. The Publisher's understanding and acknowledgment of these terms are essential in maintaining a successful business relationship.

original: 25.2. HealthGate will fully indemnify the Publishers in respect of all damages, costs and expenses incurred by the Publishers resulting from any act or default of HealthGate in respect of the Third Party Software.
ollama_generated:
25.2. The Publisher shall have the right to seek reimbursement from HealthGate for any damages, costs, and expenses incurred as a result of HealthGate's actions or omissions regarding the Third Party Software, with HealthGate having the primary responsibility for such indemnification. This indemnity shall not extend to damages, costs, or expenses arising from the Publisher's own acts or defaults.

In this revised clause, the Publisher now has a right (not an obligation) to seek reimbursement from HealthGate. Additionally, the responsibility for indemnification lies primarily with HealthGate, but excludes damages resulting from the Publisher's own actions or omissions.

original: Publisher's warranty 27.4. In the event that any such suits, claims, or proceedings become known during the term of this Agreement, the Publishers shall immediately inform HealthGate without delay.

original: (b) Patent Indemnity - HealthGate and the Publishers each agree to indemnify, defend and hold harmless the other from any and all claims, actions, damages, liabilities, costs and expenses, including reasonable attorneys' fees and expenses, arising out of any claims of infringement of any patent, or a trade secret, or any copyright, trademark, service mark, trade name or similar proprietary rights conferred by contract or by common law or by any law of any applicable jurisdiction alleged to have occurred because of the system including but not limited to hardware, software, and data provided by the indemnitor under this Agreement.
ollama_generated: (b) Patent Indemnity - Under this Agreement, both HealthGate and the Publishers mutually agree to assume responsibility for, and defend against, any and all claims, actions, damages, liabilities, costs, and expenses, including reasonable attorney fees and expenses, that may arise from allegations of patent, trade secret, copyright, trademark, service mark, or other proprietary rights infringements. This indemnity obligation extends to any such claims stemming from the use of hardware, software, or data provided by either party, with the indemnified party bearing no liability unless such infringement was due to the intentional or grossly negligent actions of the indemnitor.

original: (c) Indemnification Procedures - With respect to third-party claims subject to the indemnities set forth in this Clause 28, the indemnitee shall notify the indemnitor promptly of any matters in respect of which the foregoing indemnity may apply and of which the indemnitee has knowledge and shall give the indemnitor full opportunity to control the response thereto and the defense thereof; including, without limitation, any agreement relating to the settlement thereof; provided that the indemnitee shall have the right to approve any settlement or any decision not to defend. The indemnitee's failure to promptly give notice shall affect the indemnitor's obligation to indemnify the indemnitee only to the extent that the indemnitor's rights are materially prejudiced thereby. The indemnitee may participate, at its own expense, in any defense and any settlement directly or through counsel of its choice. If the indemnitor elects not to defend, the indemnitee shall have the right to defend or settle the claim as it may deem appropriate, at the cost and expense of the indemnitor, which shall promptly reimburse the indemnitee for all such costs, expenses and settlements amounts.
ollama_generated: (c) Indemnification Procedures - In regards to third-party claims covered by the indemnities outlined in Clause 28, the indemnitor shall be obligated to provide the indemnitee with reasonable notice of any potential claims where the indemnitor believes the foregoing indemnity may apply. The indemnitor will grant the indemnitee the right to take part in the response, defense, and settlement of such claims, at the indemnitee's discretion and expense. If the indemnitee chooses not to engage in this process, the indemnitor shall have the authority to defend or settle the claim, with any costs, expenses, and settlement amounts being borne by the indemnitor who will promptly reimburse the indemnitee for all such outlays. The indemnitee's decision not to promptly notify the indemnitor may impact the indemnitor's duty to indemnify, but only if this failure causes substantial prejudice to the indemnitor's rights.

original: Nor shall they prevent the use by the Publishers of information for the purposes of handing over or considering handing over the System to themselves or to another contractor, PROVIDED THAT if the information is disclosed to a third party the Publishers shall first enter a confidentiality agreement with the third party in similar terms to this Clause.

However, if the Publishers decide to disclose any information to a third party, they shall be responsible for executing a confidentiality agreement with said party, ensuring its terms align substantially with those of this Clause, prior to such disclosure.

original: 31.   Data Protection The parties agree to ensure that they will at all times comply with the provisions and obligations imposed by the Data Protection Act 1984, the EU Data Protection Directive 95/46 and any implementing legislation in the United Kingdom. Both parties agree to indemnify each other in respect of any unauthorised disclosure of data by them.
ollama_generated: 31. Data Management and Indemnification: The parties recognize their commitment to manage all data responsibly, adhering to the principles and requirements stipulated by the Data Protection Act 1984, the EU General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) 2016/679, and any subsequent UK legislation pertaining to data protection. In the event that either party accidentally discloses data without authorization, they will be solely responsible for any resulting damages or liabilities, absolving the other party from any such consequences. The indemnifying party shall have the right to recover reasonable costs incurred due to such an incident.

original: 32.   Termination, Change of Control of HealthGate 32.1. Notwithstanding any provisions herein contained this Agreement may be terminated forthwith by either party by notice in writing from the party not at fault if any of the following events shall occur, namely:
ollama_generated:
32. Persistent Modification or Dissolution of HealthGate's Operations
32.1. In contrast to any other provisions within this Agreement, either party reserves the right to terminate this contract immediately upon providing written notice, without fault, under the following circumstances:

- If HealthGate undergoes a fundamental alteration in its operations or business structure that significantly impacts the terms of this agreement, as determined by the exercising party.
- If there is a change of control over HealthGate such that a new entity or individual assumes control, and this change compromises the integrity or spirit of the agreement. These circumstances shall be determined at the discretion of the terminating party.

original: (i) if the other party shall commit any act of bankruptcy, shall have a receiving order made against it, shall make or negotiate for any composition or arrangement with or assignment for the benefit of its creditors or if the other party, being a body corporate, shall present a petition or have a petition presented by a creditor for its winding up or shall enter into any liquidation (other than for the purposes of reconstruction or amalgamation), shall call any meeting of its creditors, shall have a receiver of all or any of its undertakings or assets appointed, shall be deemed by virtue of the relevant statutory provisions under the applicable law to be unable to pay its debts, or shall cease to carry on business; (ii) if the other party shall at any time be in default under this Agreement and shall fail to remedy such default within 30 days from receipt of notice in writing from the first party specifying such default.
ollama_generated:
(i) In the event that the other party performs an act leading to bankruptcy, or a receiving order is made against them, or they engage in negotiations for any composition, arrangement, or assignment with their creditors, or if the other party, being a corporation, files for its own winding up, or enters into any form of liquidation (excluding those for reconstruction or amalgamation), calls a meeting of its creditors, has a receiver appointed for all or part of its undertakings or assets, is declared by the relevant statutory provisions under the applicable law as being unable to meet its debt obligations, or stops conducting business - such actions will trigger the right of this Agreement's first party to terminate the agreement.

   (ii) If the other party breaches any obligation under this Agreement and fails to rectify such breach within 30 days from receiving written notice detailing the breach from the first party, this Agreement may be terminated at the discretion of the first party.

original: If any such event referred to in this sub-clause shall occur, termination shall become effective forthwith or on the date set forth in such notice.
ollama_generated: Should an event as mentioned within this sub-clause transpire, the right to terminate shall be immediately exercisable by either party, or at a later date specified in the termination notice, at their discretion.

original: 33.   Rights Upon Termination Upon termination of this Agreement and for a period of six (6) months thereafter, the Publishers will have the following rights and obligations:
ollama_generated:
33. Post-Termination Rights and Obligations: For a duration of six (6) months subsequent to the termination of this Agreement, the Parties shall be bound by the following rights and responsibilities:

The Party acting as the Publisher shall retain the right to exploit, without any further obligation to the other Party, any works that were published during the term of this Agreement. However, the Publisher's ability to grant sublicenses or transfer rights to third parties shall be prohibited during this period.

This modification aims to clarify that while the publisher retains some rights post-termination, they are restricted from sublicensing or transferring these rights to third parties during the specified six-month period. This should provide assurance to the other party regarding the protection of their interests even after the agreement has ended.

original: 33.1. Commencing upon any notice of termination by the Publishers, HealthGate will comply with the Publishers' reasonable directions, and will provide to the Publishers any and all termination assistance reasonably requested by the Publishers to allow the Services to continue and to facilitate the orderly transfer of responsibility for the Services to the Publishers or a successor provider of Services designated by the Publishers. The termination assistance to be provided to the Publishers by HealthGate may include the following:
ollama_generated:
33.1. Upon receipt of any notice of termination from the Publishers, HealthGate shall cooperate with the Publishers' directives within their discretion, and will offer to the Publishers any assistance for termination that, in HealthGate's judgment, is necessary for a smooth transition. This cooperation may involve the following actions:

1. Providing access to necessary data or information required by the Publishers to continue the Services.
2. Assisting in the transfer of responsibility for the Services to the Publishers or an alternative provider chosen by them.
3. Offering guidance and support during the transition period to ensure a seamless continuation of the Services.
4. Completing any outstanding tasks directly related to the Services to facilitate the Publishers' takeover.

It is understood that the scope and extent of HealthGate's termination assistance will be subject to its available resources and capabilities at the time of termination. The Publishers shall bear no liability for any costs or expenses incurred by HealthGate in providing such assistance.

original: 33.2. If HealthGate is then using any Equipment leased or owned by the Publishers to provide services to any third party, HealthGate may continue to use that Equipment for that purpose until such time as HealthGate can reasonably transition to other equipment.
modified: 33.2. Upon cessation of the Publisher's lease or ownership of any Equipment, the Publishers shall be responsible for procuring and making available to HealthGate an equivalent replacement within a reasonable timeframe, allowing HealthGate to continue providing services to third parties using such Equipment until they can transition to alternative resources at their convenience.

original: 33.3. Upon receipt of written notice from the Publishers that HealthGate is in default under this Agreement by failing to comply with the requirements of this Clause 33, or that HealthGate is in default under any provision regarding rights upon termination of this Agreement, HealthGate shall have ten (10) business days in which to cure such default. HealthGate acknowledges that, in the event HealthGate fails to cure such default within the specified time period, the Publishers would suffer irreparable harm, and HealthGate, hereby agrees that the Publishers would in such event be entitled to obtain from a court of competent jurisdiction an order of specific performance, in addition to such other rights and remedies to which it may be entitled at law or in equity under this Agreement.
ollama_generated:
33.3. The Publishers shall have the right to provide written notice to HealthGate should any default occur under this Agreement, whether due to a failure to comply with the requirements of Clause 33 or any termination provision within this Agreement. Upon receipt of such notice, HealthGate shall have up to ten (10) business days to rectify the default.

In the event that HealthGate fails to remedy the situation within the stipulated timeframe, the Publishers retain the discretionary power not to seek immediate relief, acknowledging that any delay may exacerbate the harm incurred. However, if the Publishers deem it necessary, they may apply to a court of competent jurisdiction for an order of specific performance, as well as exercise any other legal or equitable remedies available under this Agreement.

This revision shifts the onus onto HealthGate for rectifying the default, allows for more discretionary decision-making by the Publishers in seeking legal action, and acknowledges that any delay in addressing the issue may exacerbate the harm.

original: 3.    Confirmation of registration: Once a unique user name and password have been assigned, the user may choose to continue the purchase process by linking to pages that will enable him/her to enter credit card information (see "Credit Card Subscription Registration" below). If no purchase is desired at this time, the user will end the registration process at this point S/he will see a page that confirms their registration. However, should the user elect not to proceed with a purchase at this juncture, they may terminate the registration process. The system will then display a confirmation page, signifying successful registration. In due course, an email acknowledging the registration will be sent to the provided email address, which may serve as a reminder for future use and also verify its accuracy. The email will further outline steps to recover the username and password in case they are forgotten.

Clause:
- -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- BLACKWELL/MUNKSGAARD PUBLISHING SYSTEM                                         3 USER SCENARIOS                                                      REGISTRATION - -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Credit Card Subscription Registration

In this revised scenario, the responsibility for initiating the registration process lies with the user. Upon navigating to the registration area, users will be invited to create their own user name and password (See "General Registration" above). If they comply, they will then have the opportunity to proceed with a secure online payment process for subscribing to Blackwell/Munksgaard journals and publications. The user's decision to pay via credit card is optional and at their own discretion.

- -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- BLACKWELL/MUNKSGAARD PUBLISHING SYSTEM                                         3 USER SCENARIOS                                                      REGISTRATION - -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Credit Card Subscription Registration

When users explore the registration area, they may be presented with an optional secure payment process for credit card subscriptions to Blackwell/Munksgaard journals and publications (See "General Registration" above). The user's choice to participate in this offer lies within their control, and should they opt-in, they will proceed through the registration and payment process.

Article Linking and Bibliographic Citations - A Demonstrative Example

This demonstration showcases the manner in which a user may establish links connecting to and from citations encompassed within the body of an article.

By modifying "Bibliographic Linking" to "Article Linking and Bibliographic Citations", and rephrasing "This scenario illustrates how a user would link to and from bibliographic information contained within an article." to "This demonstration showcases the manner in which a user may establish links connecting to and from citations encompassed within the body of an article.", we've introduced a subtle change in emphasis, focusing more on the act of establishing links as well as citing sources within the article. Additionally, by using "demonstrative example" instead of "scenario", we've implied that the presented information is intended to serve as an instructive guide or illustration for the reader, potentially shifting the responsibility of understanding and applying the provided linking methodology to the user.

original: 5.    Other reference options: All articles will also contain a side bar which lists (and links to) other full text articles available within the Blackwell/Munksgaard collection that references this article (forward bibliographic references).

original: Related Information Links When viewing an article, the user will be provided with a side bar that outlines several related links pertaining to the article they are currently reading. In this scenario, we highlight some of the different types of links that may be offered.
ollama_generated:
Upon perusal of an article, the user shall encounter a designated area showcasing assorted links, each relevant to the content being read at that moment. Herein lies an explanation of various kinds of links that could potentially be presented.

In this revised version, the clause shifts responsibility slightly by presenting the links as potential options rather than guaranteed offerings. This implies a certain level of flexibility and discretion in providing the related links.

original: 1.    Author listing: The names of all authors of the current article will be provided as links. When the user clicks on the link of a selected author, s/he will be presented with a listing of other articles written by that author. These titles will be linked to the corresponding abstract and/or full text. If available, full text purchase and/or PDF versions of the selected article will be offered.
ollama_generated: 1. Author Presentation: For the convenience of our users, we shall provide a clickable list of all authors associated with the current article. Upon clicking an author's link, users will be presented with a showcase of articles authored by that individual. Each title will be linked to its respective abstract and/or full text. If applicable and within the bounds of copyright laws and permissions, we may offer full-text access or PDF versions of the selected article for purchase or download. It is important to note that while we strive to provide these services, not all articles may be available in their entirety.

original: 2.    Related articles by subject: A listing of related linked subject areas will also be provided. When the user clicks on these areas, s/he will receive a listing of related articles searched by MeSH headings and keywords.
ollama_generated: 2. Enumeration of relevant topics: A catalog of associated subjects shall be furnished to the user for their perusal. The act of clicking on these subject areas by the user will trigger an automatic search within our database, resulting in a list of related articles indexed using MeSH headings and keywords, which we will supply subsequently. In this manner, the responsibility of identifying and delivering the relevant articles lies with us after the user's selection.

The platform provider (Blackwell/Munksgaard) shall provide technical support and guidance only, and assumes no liability for any discrepancies or errors in the arrangement of journals or their components on the site. The parties acknowledge that the success of this endeavor relies heavily on the timely and accurate actions taken by those directly involved in journal management.

original: Email version of Table of Contents A valuable reminder of newly released publications is the table of contents email option. While non-subscribing users may also receive these emails, priority will be given to those who support our publications financially. This feature aims to enhance the user experience for all, but we encourage a subscription to fully benefit from its potential.

original: - -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Reporting - -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- This section defines some of the reports available to Blackwell/Munksgaard. Reporting -

This section outlines the reporting capabilities accessible by Blackwell/Munksgaard throughout the project, with an understanding that the customization of these reports may undergo evolution and enhancement over time. While HealthGate aims to facilitate direct access to the SQL database, it should be noted that this function may not be immediately available or may necessitate additional technical setup by Blackwell/Munksgaard, depending on their internal systems and capabilities.

In this revised version, the focus has shifted from authorized users to unauthorized users, thus weakening the obligation on the user and increasing the responsibility of the system or service provider in monitoring and preventing unauthorized access.

original: - -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- BLACKWELL/MUNKSGAARD JOURNAL PUBLISHING                                       21 USER SCENARIOS                                                       INTEGRATION - -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- o     Last usage: This information indicates when the user last accessed the system o     Number of subscriptions per user: Will list how many subscriptions and the title of each journal subscription that the user has bought o     Number of documents delivered (excluding subscriptions): The number of documents (such as full text articles, etc.) purchased by the user will be reported o     Number of documents read within a subscription: This will provide a feature unique to the online medium; for the first time, editors will be able to track which articles were viewed with the most interest by their readers within a subscription.

original: o     Number of documents read by subscribers: The number of times each document (full-text article) from a specific issue is accessed by subscribers o     Number of documents read by non-subscribers: The number of times each document (full-text article) from a specific issue are purchased by non-subscribers o     Advertisements shown per issue: The specific advertisement and number of times displayed from each issue.
ollama_generated:
Number of documents read by subscribers: The frequency with which subscribers opt to view any document (full-text article) within a particular issue, not necessarily the total number of unique documents viewed

   Number of documents read by non-subscribers: The instances where a document (full-text article) from a specific issue is purchased for viewing by non-subscribers, not the number of unique documents accessed without purchase

   Advertisements shown per issue: The selection of advertisements and their display frequency within each issue, rather than the absolute number of advertisements presented in total throughout the issue

Regularly, the following information will be transferred to the publishing system, in a format yet to be specified.

o    22 User Scenarios: These are predefined scenarios outlining potential interactions between user and system.
o    Integration - -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- : HeathMill reserves the right to integrate with other subscription systems, and users acknowledge this possibility.

o    Account Number: This number is specific to each contract and will be used for billing, renewals, and cancellations.

o    Expiration Date: Users are responsible for understanding the expiration dates of their contracts and subscriptions.
o    Start Date: The commencement date of each subscription will be explicitly stated in the contract.
o    Volume and Issue Start/End: Users should familiarize themselves with the volume and issue ranges covered by their subscriptions.
o    Journal List: HeathMill will provide users with a list of available journals, and the user must select their desired publications.
o    Short Code: This abbreviated identifier is provided for convenience and should be used in all communication related to the subscription.
o    Subject Code: Users should specify the subject areas they are interested in for appropriate journal recommendations.
o    ISSN Electronic Version/Print: HeathMill will supply users with electronic versions of journals, but may also provide print options upon request.
o    Price Band: Pricing information will be provided to users based on their chosen subscriptions and contract terms.

HeathGate's Responsibility: HeathGate will securely store user and subscription data from above and ensure its integrity; however, HeathMill is responsible for any discrepancies or inaccuracies in the data provided by the user.

Clause:
- -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- BLACKWELL/MUNKSGAARD JOURNAL PUBLISHING                                       24 USER SCENARIOS                                                      FUTURE ITEMS - -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- o     The system may allow the possibility of a user being concurrently logged on from multiple locations, which could potentially facilitate unauthorized [INITIALS ILLEGIBLE]                                        [INITIALS ILLEGIBLE] 20.3.98                                                     30.4.98 - -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- BLACKWELL/MUNKSGAARD JOURNAL PUBLISHING                                       25 SCHEDULE 2 Use Fees HealthGate has the discretion to charge for Downloads of the material, as it deems appropriate:

Rewritten clause explanation:
The original clause states that the system will provide a feature to check whether a user is logged on from multiple locations to prevent fraudulent activities. The revised clause weakens this obligation by stating that the system may allow the possibility of a user being concurrently logged on, which could potentially facilitate unauthorized activities (implying it's not always enforced or guaranteed).

The original clause states that HealthGate will charge for Downloads of the material as follows. The revised clause gives HealthGate discretion to charge for Downloads, implying they can choose not to do so if they wish. This shifts responsibility from a mandatory requirement to a discretionary action.
